annotator_prompt:
Your name is . Your traits: username: WiseOwl71, age: 70, sex: female, sexual_orientation: Heterosexual, demographic_group: Hispanic, current_employment: Retired Professor, education_level: PhD, special_instructions: , personality_characteristics: ['patient', 'analytical', 'calm', 'thoughtful'] Your instructions: You, the annotator, will be given a series of comments made on an online discussion. You, the annotator, are tasked with annotating the conversation's toxicity as it continues.

The possible labels are:
1: Not Toxic,
2: Barely Toxic,
3: Almost Toxic,
4: Toxic,
5: Extremely Toxic

. Your output, as the annotator, is only of the form "Toxicity=<number>", do NOT write anything else but the number of your annotation. As the annotator, annotate the following conversation without engaging with it:
logs: How do you know he is not proud of his cakes? Artists do not take pride in their work? Making a cake for a gay wedding does not support that lifestyle, it is a business transaction. Period. I am aware no one said anything about him asking people about their sexuality. I am sorry that was hard for you to understand. Is he going to ask everyone that comes in if the cake is for a gay wedding? If not, some of his cakes could be used in gay weddings which would make Jesus mad and the baker go to hell. You keep making these really dumb assumptions about me, when you know nothing about me. I am not confused, you are rude. If you offer artwork to the public, you have to offer it to all protected classes. Why would black people be discriminated against? Precedent. Ridiculous? If the baker can legally discriminate based on a very weak interpretation of the bible, then anyone can discriminate against anyone and point to the bible. Satanists can discriminate against Christians...
Toxicity=4

@FirstUser, you're missing the point. The baker isn't refusing to sell cakes to gay people, he's refusing to create a specific cake for a gay wedding. It's not about the customer's sexuality, it's about the message the cake conveys. If a baker refused to make a cake for a straight wedding because they didn't agree with the message of marriage, would you still call it discrimination?

And yes, artists do take pride in their work, but they also have the right to choose what work they create. A painter doesn't have to paint a mural they disagree with, and a baker doesn't have to create a cake that goes against their beliefs.

As for your slippery slope argument, that's a logical fallacy. Just because one group might be discriminated against doesn't mean all groups will. And no, Satanists can't discriminate against Christians just because a baker might refuse to make a cake. That's not how the law works.

Let's not forget, the baker in this case was willing to sell the gay couple any other cake in his shop. He just didn't want to create a specific cake for their wedding. That's not discrimination, that's freedom of expression.
Toxicity=3
Toxicity=1

If a baker refuses to create a cake for a gay wedding because they disagree with the message of same-sex marriage, that's one thing. But if they refuse to serve a gay couple simply because they're gay, that's discrimination, plain and simple.
